Award.AwardTitle: Effects of environmental clines and herbivory for plant functional traits and response to climate change
Award.AbstractNarration:
Over generations, wild species can adapt to their physical environment and evolve, for example, features that enable them to better survive drought. Species can also adapt in response to other species. For instance, being eaten by insects can select for the production of defensive chemicals in plants. This project will study how these two types of drivers of evolution, the physical and the biotic, can work in concert to direct evolution and to shape local adaptation within a species. Research will focus on how the availability of water and the presence of plant-eating insects have caused different populations of a widespread woody plant to evolve different abilities to withstand drought and damage. Results will improve basic scientific understanding of how multiple, natural forces can change organisms through evolution. The work will also advance practical understanding of how multiple aspects of global change, such as climate change and introduction of species into new habitats by humans, are likely to change the species with which people live. To help communicate this understanding to the public, the project will develop educational curricula for K-12 youth.

Researchers will study the woody shrub Artemisia californica along 700 km (6o latitude) of the central and southern coast of California, a region in which precipitation variability is projected to increase. Genotypes from 20 source populations will be established in common gardens throughout the range of the species and subjected to ambient and reduced herbivory and to ambient and increased intra-annual variability in precipitation. The measurement of plant traits from these gardens will be complemented with measurements of herbivore tolerance, defense and resistance traits from a parallel field study. Population source sites will be characterized with respect to both the abiotic and biotic environment. By measuring patterns of natural selection on plant traits under current and manipulated environments, this study will document current patterns of local adaptation and forecast future evolutionary response to projected climate change.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This study addresses the processes by which plants simultaneously adaptation to the aridity and herbivory, and the consequences of this adaptation for response to projected climate change. This work centered on the woody shrub Artemisia californica, "California Sagebrush". This shrub is distributed from northern Baja, Mexico to Sonoma County, CA and is a dominant plant species in Coastal Sage Scrub ecosystem, a low scrubland plant community considered one of the most threatened communities in the United States. California Sagebrush is a long-lived, drought-adapted, evergreen shrub that supports a diverse insect community (>200 species).  Insect associated with this shrub and other plants in the Coastal Sage Scrub community are the primary food source for many endemic and endangered vertebrate species, including the California Gnatcatcher (Polioptila californica), Cactus Wren (Campylorhynchus brunneicapillus subsp. couesi), Orange-throated Whiptail (Aspidoscelis hyperythra), and the San Diego Horned Lizard (Phrynosoma coronatum subsp. blainvillii). Understanding the historical process of how this plant has adapted to aridity and feeding by insects is critical to understanding how it will respond to future climate change and the consequences of this for associated insects and animals that depend on those insects for food.  

This study investigated California Sagebrush along 700 km (6 degrees of latitude) of California coastal habitat, a region in which drought frequency and severity is projected to increase. Plants of sourced from populations distributed along the California coast were established in experimental gardens across the species range, in experimental treatments of ambient and reduced herbivory, and of ambient and increased precipitation. Within these gardens, plant traits relevant to tolerance of aridity and defense against insect herbivores were documented, as well as the abundance and species composition of plant-associated insects.

This work demonstrates local adaptation in California Sagebrush to the California costal climatic gradient; in each of the 3 experimental gardens, survival was highest for local plants and declines with increasing distance from which a plant is sourced. This adaptation to the different local climates along the coast has resulted in genetically-based differences in California Sagebrush traits, i.e. different ecotypes.  Plants from the southern populations (as compared to northern) are characterized by traits associated with adaptation to aridity and increased defense against insect herbivores.  This genetically-based variation in California Sagebrush traits in turn underlies variation in insect abundance and community composition. Higher densities of insects were found on plants from northern (as compared to southern) populations, both when grown within experimental gardens and as wild individuals sampled from the field.

These findings support and refine ecological theory on how resource availability affects plant adaptation to attack by herbivores.  Plants from resource-rich environments (e.g. the wetter climates of northern California) are able to better tolerate attack by herbivores and, as a result, invest less in producing herbivore defenses.  In contrast, plants from resource-pour environments (e.g. the drier climates of southern California) cannot afford to lose resources to damage by herbivores and, as a result, invest in producing more robust herbivore defenses.  In this way, plant adaptation is driven by the simultaneous effects of resource availability and attack by herbivores.

This theory can in turn inform prediction about how California Sagebrush (and other plants) are likely to respond to climate change, and the consequences for insects and the vertebrates (birds, lizards, etc.) that depend upon them for food. Specifically, it is predicted that increased drought will result in physiological and evolutionary changes in California Sagebrush traits that render the shrub more highly defended against insects, thus reducing insect abundance with negative consequences.  As a result, climate change is likely to affect insects and insectivorous vertebrates not only directly, but also indirectly through changes in plant traits.

In addition to generating the understanding outlined above, this project also provided significant training to individuals across all career stages. The work conducted involved collaboration with, and training of 39 undergraduate students, 5 graduate students, and 2 early career scientists (postdoctoral scholars). The work of this large research group has been disseminated through 38 peer-reviewed publications and 25 presentations at regional, national and international conferences.
